questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents to the clinic with a persistent cough lasting for 2 weeks. The cough consists of rapid, consecutive coughs followed by an inspiratory gasp and post-tussive vomiting. The child's 5-year-old sibling, who attends preschool, developed similar symptoms 10 days ago.Based on the clinical presentation and exposure history described, what is the likelihood that the child's sibling will develop similar symptoms within the next few weeks?
questions.solution:
Answer: D) >90%

 

Explanation:

  • The secondary attack rate refers to the probability that an infection will occur among susceptible individuals after exposure to an infected person.
  • The secondary attack rate of pertussis is greater than 90%.
  • Measles has a secondary attack rate of >80%, with cyclical seasonal outbreaks occurring every 2–3 years in unvaccinated populations.
  • Mumps has a secondary attack rate of 86%.

 

Disease

Agent

Source

Period of Communicability

Host Factors

Mumps

ssRNA virus of the family Paramyxovirus.

Cases and subclinical cases

4 to 6 days before onset of symptoms and 1 week after.

Affects children between 5-9 years old.

Both genders can be affected.

Measles
(Rubeola)

ssRNA virus of the family Paramyxoviruses.

Only one serotype is responsible for infection thus single infection provides lifelong immunity

Subclinical and clinical cases of measles

4 days before and 4-5 days after the appearance of rash.

In developing countries: 6 months-3 years.

In developed countries: > 5 years.

M=F.

Malnutrition is a predisposing factor (Especially Vitamin A deficiency).

Rubella (or 3-day measles or German Measles)

ssRNA virus of the family Togavirus.

It has one antigenic variant.

Cases and subclinical cases. Infants born with congenital rubella may shed the virus for many months.

1 week before the rash and 1 week after rash.

Seen in developing countries.

Age group: 3-10 years.

M=F.

Pertussis

Bordetella pertussis.

Para pertussis is responsible in 5% cases.

Cases of pertussis.

1 week post-exposure till 3 weeks after onset of paroxysmal stage.

Age: <5 years.

Highest mortality in children <6 months.

Incidence and mortality are more among females.

questions.text:
Match the following pathogen with its incubation period?

 


	
		
			
			Pathogen
			
			
			Incubation period
			
		
		
			
			A. Mumps
			
			
			1. 7-10 days
			
		
		
			
			B. Measles
			
			
			2. 18 days
			
		
		
			
			C. Rubella
			
			
			3. 14-21 days
			
		
		
			
			D. Pertussis
			
			
			4. 7-14 days
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) A-3, B-1, C-2, D-4

Explanation:

Infectious Diseases – WHO Format

Disease

Causative Agent

Mode of Transmission

Incubation Period

Remarks

Measles

Measles virus

Droplet & droplet nuclei

10–14 days

Rash appears ~14 days; endemic with periodic epidemics

Mumps

Mumps virus

Droplet & direct contact

14–21 days (avg 16–18 days)

Iceberg phenomenon; endemic

Rubella

Rubella virus

Droplet & droplet nuclei

14–21 days (avg ~18 days)

Epidemics occur every 5–7 years

Chickenpox (Varicella)

Varicella-zoster virus

Airborne, droplet, direct contact

10–21 days (avg 14–16 days)

Highly contagious

Pertussis (Whooping Cough)

Bordetella pertussis

Droplet & direct contact

7–14 days (may extend to 3 weeks)

Endemic; catarrhal stage follows incubation

Diphtheria

Corynebacterium diphtheriae

Droplet, contact with infected secretions

2–5 days (range up to 10 days)

Requires antitoxin + antibiotics

Influenza

Influenza virus

Droplet, direct contact

1–4 days (avg ~2 days)

Rapid onset; seasonal epidemics

COVID-19

SARS-CoV-2

Droplet, aerosol, contact

2–14 days (avg 5–6 days)

Incubation varies by variant

Syphilis

Treponema pallidum

Sexual, transplacental

10–90 days (avg ~21 days)

Chancre appears ~3 weeks post-exposure

Hepatitis A

HAV

Feco-oral

15–50 days (avg ~28 days)

Waterborne outbreaks possible

Hepatitis B

HBV

Parenteral, sexual, perinatal

30–180 days (avg ~75 days)

Asymptomatic during incubation

Tetanus

Clostridium tetani

Contaminated wounds

3–21 days (avg ~8 days)

Severity ↑ with shorter incubation

Rabies

Rabies virus

Animal bites (saliva)

1–3 months (can range 1 week–1 year)

Depends on bite site & viral load

Typhoid Fever

Salmonella typhi

Feco-oral

7–14 days

Gradual onset of fever

Cholera

Vibrio cholerae

Feco-oral (contaminated water)

2 hours–5 days (avg 1–2 days)

Sudden explosive outbreaks

Dengue

Dengue virus

Mosquito-borne (Aedes aegypti)

4–7 days

After bite of infected mosquito

Leptospirosis

Leptospira interrogans

Contact with animal urine-contaminated water

2–30 days (avg 7–12 days)

Occupational risk; biphasic illness

Hand-Foot-Mouth Disease

Coxsackie A virus

Feco-oral, respiratory secretions

3–6 days

Common in young children

Polio

Poliovirus

Feco-oral, oral-oral

7–14 days

May be asymptomatic or paralytic

HIV/AIDS (Acute Phase)

HIV

Sexual, blood, perinatal

2–6 weeks

Acute retroviral syndrome during seroconversion

Malaria

Plasmodium spp.

Mosquito-borne (Anopheles)

7–30 days

P. falciparum: shorter incubation

Tuberculosis

Mycobacterium tuberculosis

Airborne

Weeks to months

Latent TB has undefined incubation period

Bacillus cereus food poisoning

Bacillus cereus

Ingestion of contaminated food

1–6 hours

Associated with reheated rice

Staphylococcal food poisoning

Staph. aureus

Ingestion of preformed toxin

1–8 hours

Common in cream/pastry-based food

Botulism

Clostridium botulinum

Ingestion of toxin

18–36 hours

Neuroparalysis; emergency

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with a low-grade fever for the past 5 days . Upon examination, the child appears as shown below. Which of the following is true about this condition?

choices.text: It is the leading cause of pancreatitis in children
Infectious cause of conductive hearing loss
0.5 ml of Jeryl Lynn strain vaccine given intradermally
Septic meningitis is a common complication

questions.solution:
Answer: A) It is the leading cause of pancreatitis in children

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical vignette suggests mumps (low-grade fever + bilateral parotitis). The true statement regarding this condition is that mumps is the leading cause of pancreatitis in children.

 

Complications

Orchitis

The most common extra salivary gland manifestation of mumps in post pubertal patients.

Common among adolescents and is usually unilateral.

Oophoritis

Most common among adolescents and is mostly unilateral.

Pancreatitis

Mumps is the leading cause of pancreatitis in children.

Aseptic Meningitis

The most common complication of mumps. (Option D)

Sensorineural Deafness

Mumps is one of the most common infectious causes of sensorineural hearing loss. (Option B)

 

Vaccines:

 

Feature

Description

Vaccine Strain
  • Jeryl Lynn (recommended);
  • Leningrad 3, RIT 4385, L-Zagreb, Urabe (other strains)
  • Rubini strain is NOT recommended by WHO

ROA & Dosage

Intramuscular &0.5 ml (Option C ruled out)

Age

> 1 year of age

Schedule
  • Can be given alone, or as MMR or MR combined vaccine
  • As per National immunization schedule
    • First at 9 months till 12 months as MR-1
    • Second dose recommended at 16-24 months as MR-2

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the pediatric clinic to receive the third dose of the DPT (Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus) vaccine. Which of the following is a potential side effect of the pertussis component of the vaccine?
questions.solution:
Answer: D) Inconsolable cry

 

Explanation:

 

DPT Vaccine:

 

DPT (Diphtheria, pertussis, tetanus) vaccine

Components

Diphtheria toxoid: 25 Lf (limit of flocculation).

Tetanus toxoid: 5 Lf.

Pertussis killed acellular bacilli: 20,000 million.

Dose

0.5 ml

Route of administration

Intramuscular

Site

Anterolateral aspect of left thigh

Schedule

Can be given as DPT or pentavalent vaccine at 6 weeks, 10 weeks, 14 weeks.

1st booster dose at 16-24 months.

2d booster dose at 5-6 years.

In case of delayed vaccination, DPT can be given till 7 years of age while PENTAVALENT can be given up to 1 year of age only.

Adjuvant

Aluminum phosphate (2.5 mg): Increases immunogenicity of vaccine

Preservative

Thiomersal (0.01%)

Adverse effects
  • Fever and mild local reaction common following DPT vaccine.
  • Due to pertussis component: Inconsolable cry, Reye’s syndrome, Hypotensive hyporesponsive encephalopathy (HHE) (option D).

Contraindications
  • If severe reactions such as collapse/shock, temperature > 40°C and anaphylaxis occurred after the previous dose.
  • In such cases, the next part of the vaccine should not contain the pertussis component.
  • Persistent inconsolable crying for more than 2 hours following DPT/pentavalent vaccination is not an absolute contraindication to subsequent doses.

 

Intussusception (Option A): is commonly a potential side effect seen with the Rotavirus vaccine.

 

Toxic shock syndrome (Option B): is seen with the MMR vaccine.

 

Guillain-Barré syndrome (Option C): is more commonly associated with Influenza vaccine.

questions.text: A 4 Y/o girl has been brought to the clinic with a high fever, cough, runny nose, and red eyes for the past three days associated with a red, blotchy rash that started on her face and has now spread to her trunk and limbs. On examination, greyish-white spots on the buccal mucosa are noticed. If this febrile illness is caused by a ssRNA paramyxovirus, which of the following is most specific for making a clinical diagnosis in this child?

choices.text: Grayish white spots on buccal mucosa
Rash from face spread to trunk and limbs

questions.solution:
Answer: B) Grayish white spots on buccal mucosa

 

Explanation: Based on the above scenario, the child is most probably suffering from measles, which is caused by a ssRNA paramyxovirus and the most specific clinical feature for it is presence of Grayish white spots on buccal mucosa.

 

Measles

Causative agent
  • ssRNA paramyxovirus

Incubation period
  • 10 days from exposure to onset of fever and 14 days to the appearance of rash

Source of infection
  • Person with measles
  • Infective material

Period of communicability
  • 4 days before and 4 days after the appearance of rash

Clinical features

Prodromal stage:

  • Fever
  • Cough
  • Coryza with sneezing
  • Conjunctivitis with lacrimation
  • Koplik’s spots- grayish-white spots on the buccal mucosa (Pathognomonic feature) (Option B)
 

Eruptive stage:

  • Dusky red macular/maculopapular rash, which starts behind the ears and progresses to the face, neck and then to trunks and limbs.
  • In the absence of complications, the lesions and fever disappear after 3-4 days.
 

Post measles stage:

  • After the eruptive stage, it leads to weight loss, weakness, fatigue, diarrhea.

Isolation period
  • 7 days from the onset of rash

Difference between measles and rubella rash
  • Both rashes are maculopapular
  • The rash in measles is more confluent and botchy, whereas the rash in rubella is discrete or non-confluent.

Diagnosis
  • Clinically diagnosed based on rash and koplik’s spots
  • Gold standard: PCR

Treatment
  • No specific treatment
  • Symptomatic management only

 

Measles Rash

                       

Rubella rash

       

Koplik spots

questions.text: Which of the following complications is the most common cause of death in measles?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pneumonia

Explanation:

The most common complication of measles causing death is pneumonia.

COMPLICATIONS OF MEASLES

Otitis Media (Option D)

M/c complication in young children. Covered under IMNCI programme.

Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis (SSPE)

(Option B)

A rare, fatal brain disease that occurs years after measles infection, causing neurological damage and mortality

Pneumonia (Option C)

Most common fatal complication & cause of death

Persistent Diarrhea

Long-lasting diarrhea, potentially leading to protein-losing enteropathy.

Prevalent in developing countries, impacting infants significantly.

Keratomalacia

Measles causes acute vitamin A deficiency in children.

Giant Cell Pneumonia, Measles Inclusion-body Encephalitis

Primarily affects immunocompromised individuals.

Other complications: Laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup), Encephalitis, Spontaneous abortion, Premature delivery

Complications in the post-measles stage: Diarrhea, fatigue & weight loss

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the measles vaccine is incorrect?

choices.text: The measles vaccine is available in monovalent and combination forms.
The first dose of the measles vaccine is administered at 9 completed months.
The MR variant is used under the National Immunisation Schedule
The measles vaccine follows the open vial policy and can be used for multiple doses once reconstituted.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) The measles vaccine follows the open vial policy and can be used for multiple doses once reconstituted.

Explanation:
Measles vaccine is a reconstituted vaccine (freeze-dried vaccine) & does not follow open vial policy.

Measles Vaccine

Immunoglobulin (Ig)
  • Available in:
  • Monovalent (measles only), measles-rubella (MR)- Used in NIS (Option C ruled out)
  • Measles-Mumps-Rubella (MMR), and Measles-Mumps-Rubella-Varicella (MMRV) forms (Option A ruled out)
  • Strains used: Edmonston-Zagreb 
  • First dose: 9 completed months (MR1-85% protection) (Option B ruled out)
  • Administered along with JE vaccine subcutaneously.
  • Second dose: 16-24 months (MR2-98% protection)
  • In case of delayed immunization, it can be given up to 5 years.
  • MR is given in the right arm.
  • It is a reconstituted vaccine (freeze-dried vaccine) & does not follow open vial policy.
  • Post-vaccination: Measles-like illness (1-3 days)
  • Can protect susceptible contacts older than 9-12 months old from measles if given within 3 days of exposure.
  • Recommended dose: 0.25 ml per kg of body weight
  • After receiving Ig, the individual should receive the live measles vaccine 8-12 weeks later

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to be a feature of Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS)?
questions.solution:
Answer: D) Conductive hearing loss

 

Explanation:

Conductive hearing loss is not typically associated with Congenital Rubella Syndrome.

CONGENITAL RUBELLA SYNDROME

Definition
  • Congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) occurs in infants who have contracted rubella from their mothers while in utero.
  • The most likely time for this to occur is between 8-10 weeks of gestation.
  • After birth, these babies can transmit the virus to others for a period of 12–18 months.

Dermatological presentation
  • Blueberry Muffin Rash
  • Forchheimer Spots- small, red or purple spots that can appear on the soft palate

Ophthalmic Defects
  • Cataracts (Option A ruled out)
  • Microphthalmia
  • Glaucoma
  • Salt and pepper retinopathy
  • Chorioretinitis

Auditory Defects
  • Sensorineural deafness (Option B ruled out)

Cardiac Defects
  • Peripheral pulmonary artery stenosis
  • Patent ductus arteriosus (Option C ruled out)
  • Ventricular septal defects

Craniofacial Defects
  • Microcephaly

Other Infant Presentations
  • Meningoencephalitis
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Interstitial pneumonitis
  • Radiolucency in the long bones
 

Diagnosis
  • Hemagglutination inhibition test (HAI) is the commonly preferred test.
  • Presence of IgM antibodies shortly after birth.
  • Presence of IgG antibodies lasting >6 months.
  • IgM positive implies in-utero infection because IgM antibodies cannot pass from mother to child through the placenta.

 

                                                                                                          Blueberry muffin rash                                                                                                                                               

Forchheimer Spots- are small, red or purple spots that can appear on the soft palate

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the rubella-containing vaccine (RCV) is incorrect?

choices.text: The live attenuated RA 27/3 strain is used in the rubella vaccine
RCVs have a shelf-life of 2-3 years when stored at 4°C
The recommended dose of RCV is 1.0 ml injected subcutaneously
Recipients of RCV are advised not to become pregnant for 1 month after vaccination

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The recommended dose of RCV is 1.0 ml injected subcutaneously.

 

Explanation:

 

RUBELLA VACCINE AND VACCINATION STRATEGY

Strain Used

Live attenuated RA 27/3 (Option A ruled out)

Formulations

Monovalent, MR, MMR, MMRV

Dosage

Single 0.5 ml dose, subcutaneously in anterolateral thigh or outer upper arm. (Option C)

Dose Effectiveness

Single-Dose Strategy: Effective for rubella elimination if high coverage is achieved. >95% effectiveness for a single dose

Two-Dose Strategy: Practical when combined with measles vaccination using MR or MMR vaccine

Storage Conditions

RCVs: 2-8°C, protected from light

Diluent vials: Ambient temperature, not frozen

Shelf-Life

2-3 years at 4°C (Option B ruled out)

Target Groups

Priority 1: Non-pregnant women of reproductive age

Priority 2: Children between 1-14 years

Priority 3: Routine vaccination of children <1 year

Pregnancy Advisory

Recipients advised not to become pregnant for 1 month after vaccination as it increases the risk of congenital rubella syndrome. (Option D ruled out)

But it is not an indication for MTP if the woman does get pregnant within 1 month of vaccination

questions.text: What is the primary goal of the "Keep up" strategy in the WHO measles and rubella elimination strategy?

choices.text: Conducting a nationwide vaccination campaign targeting all children born after the catch-up campaign
Ensuring routine services aimed at vaccinating more than 95% of each successive birth cohort
Targeting all children 9 months to 14 years of age, irrespective of history of measles disease

questions.solution:
Answer: B) Ensuring routine services aimed at vaccinating more than 95% of each successive birth cohort

 

Explanation:

 

WHO measles and rubella elimination strategy

Catch up

Nationwide vaccination campaign targeting all children 9 months to 14 years of age, irrespective of history of measles disease or vaccination status. (Option C ruled out)

(Measles and rubella elimination campaign)

Keep up

Routine services aimed at vaccinating more than 95% of each successive birth cohort. (Option B)(Routine vaccination)

Follow up

Subsequent nationwide vaccination campaigns conducted every 2-4 years targeting usually all children born after the catch-up campaign. (Option A and D ruled out)

Global Measles & Rubella Strategic Framework (2021-2030)
  • The aim for the 2021-2030 period is to "attain and maintain the regional targets for measles and rubella elimination."
  • Integrate measles and rubella activities into primary healthcare for universal health coverage.
  • Enhance ownership and accountability for measles and rubella targets and boost community vaccination demand.
  • Identify and address immunity gaps through healthcare contact points and targeted outreach to underserved communities.
  • Adopt a life-course approach for second-dose delivery and integrate it with other health initiatives.
  • Ensure outbreak preparedness for timely detection and effective response.
  • Maintain a reliable supply of vaccines, supplies, and reagents, and secure sustainable financing.
  • Promote research and innovation to achieve high immunity and utilize quality disease and program data.
